website_summaries.verdict: Serious coffee drinkers will appreciate its ample capacity; however, handle concerns and the cumbersome design detract from its practicality.
pros: One of the larger Chemex coffee makers that can accommodate up to 8 cups at a time
cons: Size is a bit bulky and awkward to maneuver
At least one consumer reported a faulty handle that appeared to be separating from the carafe
No wood collar or leather tie

customer_reviews.title: Worth every drop.
customer_reviews.text: I assumed the Chemex was probably going to be gimmicky and too much work compared to my Keurig Vue but I was very pleasantly surprised. While it does take a fair amount more effort to produce than my other pod base coffee maker, the difference in quality is stunning. After some trial and error, I wouldn't recommend using standard filters with the Chemex but instead stay with the thicker proprietary Chemex brand filters.
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: Good replacement for a traditional Chemex
customer_reviews.text: So far so good. It makes the same wonderful tasting coffee like a traditional Chemex. This was a replacement for a traditional Chemex with the wood ring. Which broke when I knocked it too hard on something. Now I’m being VERY careful while handling it. I do like the glass handle a lot. It pours easily and doesn’t get too hot to handle safely.
customer_reviews.author: Karen

customer_reviews.title: Made in USA.  Great tasting coffee!!!!!
customer_reviews.text: Great coffee maker. So nice to have coffee without the chemicals leeched in from plastic and heavy metals from the tubing. We spray a vinegar/water mix in to clean....takes 30 seconds. We have a bunch of old, regular filters we are using up and may or may not purchase the Chemex brand filters But we do double them up, otherwise it seals into the pour spout, which acts as a vent during brewing and would cause hot coffee to shoot out of the top. The Chemex filters are stiffer and don't do this.
customer_reviews.author: superbirdman

customer_reviews.title: Great pour over for reasonable price
customer_reviews.text: I have been using a Chemex pour over carafe for probably five years or so after I got fed up with the watered down flavor from my Keurig. I had to purchase this new one when my cat knocked it off the counter as it was drying (it was empty). The flavor is superior and worth the extra bit of time it takes to be over a traditional drip coffee maker. I am the only coffee drinker in the house, so this is a good size for making 20 to 30 ounces of brew. Get a bigger carafe is you need to make more than that on the daily.
customer_reviews.author: Sarah

customer_reviews.title: Best Way to Make Coffee
customer_reviews.text: I love my Chemex so much. I like this model more than the wood handled version because the whole thing can be put through the dishwasher, and the handle is very easy to pour. The coffee I make is so much better than with the drip model I had been using, and it is fast and so simple. I typically make coffee for just one or two people, so I think I could have gotten a slightly smaller model, but 8 cups is definitely plenty. I have also started using it to filter cold brew coffee I make. It is by far the easiest method for filtering my cold brew that I have tried!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Chemex will remain our coffeemaker of choice indefinitely.
customer_reviews.text: We *love* our Chemex coffeemaker. Our first chemex was given to us as a gift by dear friends of yours. Our only question has been..."Where has this been all of our lives?". The process is simple and easy yielding a great, non-bitter result each and every time. The Chemex in combination with our japanese name-brand water boiler/warmer is a "one-two punch of coffee awesomeness". (...as well as other hot beverages) No waiting for the hot water (...at the perfect 195 F temperature btw)
customer_reviews.author: John Connors

customer_reviews.title: and like them a lot
customer_reviews.text: We've been using Chemex for years, and like them a lot. There is one reason I won't give them 5 stars: once you've used them for a while, they become brittle, you bump them a little and that's it. We've gone through 5 or so over the last 8 years or so, and we're not klutzes. Seriously, you bump a mug against it and a chunk comes out. I don't see why they wouldn't make them thicker, like pyrex dishes. My husband claims it's to make you have to buy more of them.
customer_reviews.author: Poiatica

customer_reviews.title: Can not go back to regular coffee now
customer_reviews.text: Was not a believer until i got this and began using it. Absolutely the best tasting coffee i have ever made. Zero complaints
customer_reviews.author: david gabbard

customer_reviews.title: Fragile- Not for The Hulk it Small Children
customer_reviews.text: Worked well but it was very fragile. It broke while I was washing it. If you’re the kind of responsible person that can handle delicate items then this is the cold brew pitcher for you. If you get nervous in nice stores, you may consider something else.
customer_reviews.author: jackie

customer_reviews.title: A great cup of coffee...
customer_reviews.text: Our older "pod" coffee system never seemed to meet my expectations. Using this carafe during the pour-over process makes a great cup of coffee. And, it's an attractive addition to the stove or counter top empty or full. After reading some of the reviews I have been cautious during the washing process as it does seem to be easy to break.
customer_reviews.author: Kathleen Bell

customer_reviews.title: Chemex me in!!! A must if you want real flavor in your wine..........I mean coffee
customer_reviews.text: Coffee snobs? YES we are. used French presses for years and now this and WOW WOW WOW. it did take me months to perfect the pour over, blooming, temp, grind, season, humidity, attitude method but hey once I did I cried on how good a cup I made. Now I enjoy the ZEN I get making 2 cups at a time. ya they say 8 cups.... whats that for mice?? it makes 2 average size cups 800g watter to 48-60g beans I like it a bit stronger

customer_reviews.title: Switched from the Classic
customer_reviews.text: I love these coffeemakers for their simplicity and the end product, but the glass is amazingly fragile: I've never had one last for more than about a year. We'll see if this one fares any better, but in the meantime the glass handle makes it easier to pour and clean that the wooden collar version.
customer_reviews.author: Geoffrey Ghose

customer_reviews.title: Easily breaks
customer_reviews.text: I got this product for Christmas this past year, and it was only a month and a half before it broke. As I was washing it, I barely touched the sink with it and a piece of glass broke off. I understand that glass is breakable, but the glass in this product is so thin that there's no way this product will last you a very long time. I would expect some type of warranty, but alas there is not. That's $40 down the drain.
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer Landes

customer_reviews.title: Simple, makes good coffee, classic design
customer_reviews.text: Have used these for years. They make great coffee, have no plastic parts and look good. Even though it is glass it is heat resistant and you can put ice cubes in the bottom of it to have iced coffee. Be sure to use real Chemex filters - cheap filters sometimes make the coffee taste like paper and don't get the oils out. Also get a brush to make it easier to clean out the inside.
customer_reviews.author: Acust

customer_reviews.title: The handle tho!
customer_reviews.text: My husband despises the classic Chemex wooden clamp thing and so do I. It never ages well, the wood gets saturated with water and looks gross after a few weeks of use. This handle is a DREAM. Easy to pour and looks so good on the countertop against our backsplash because it's like it's not even there.
customer_reviews.author: GabLaughin

customer_reviews.title: Very happy with my Chemex

It's as elegant looking as it is functional; however, with the elegance there is a certain delicateness of which you should be mindful. The vessel is not fragile, but I do feel the need to exercise care during cleaning or risk chipping or cracking it.
customer_reviews.author: Cool_Nerd

customer_reviews.title: Perfect

customer_reviews.author: AmandaR

customer_reviews.title: I make coffee with this every day

customer_reviews.author: Gavin Strauss

customer_reviews.title: Great coffee

Used with the Chemex filters it makes an excellent brew and we don't find it to be overly fussy. In fact, it makes for a nice conversation piece / performance art for when friends are visiting. I've never actually used the original model with the wooden collar, but I have to think this one with the glass handle is more convenient. Highly recommended with the right filters.

customer_reviews.title: Makes the best coffee

My best friend is dead set on buying himself one now too. Basically, believe the hype. This pour over makes a great cup of Joe. The only downside is that it doesn't come with a cover for keeping the heat in. If you're like me, you can cover the top with something else.I also have a knitted beanie that fits the bottom well, that I use to insulate it.

To me it is just barely more trouble than brewing in an electric maker, but you're rewarded with fabulous tasting coffee. I bought an insulated carafe at the same time to keep the coffee warm. An extra bonus has been the extra room on the cabinet top and no bulky, drippy, messy electric coffee maker sitting out.

customer_reviews.title: Chemex Coffee Maker
customer_reviews.text: Best cup of coffee ever! We use this daily and I don't find that the extra time needed to be a bother. I grind the beans while waiting for the tea kettle to boil and then slowly pour water over the coffee. The taste difference, compared to an automatic drip machine, is astonishing. Tip! Use a Chemex filter for at least two reasons: they definitely make the coffee taste better than grocery store filters and they work with the Chemex carafe opening much better.
